What is this Orange stuff, anyhow? {.center} --- ## Installing and Getting Used to Orange some stuff here --- ## Brad Pitt: Throwing it All Away {.center} --- ## Brad Pitt: Throwing it All Away
{{< video https://youtu.be/PlKDQqKh03Y height=540 width=760 title='None of them!'>}}
::: notes What was Brad Pitt throwing away? He was throwing away the individuality of the measures, subsuming them to one summary. This is a big idea in statistics, and it is called aggregation. ::: --- ## Brad Pitt: Throwing it All Away{.smaller} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="65%"} Steven Stigler (2016) in “The Seven Pillars of Statistical Wisdom”: - One of the Big Ideas in Statistics is: ***Aggregation*** - How is it revolutionary? - By stipulating that, given a number of observations, [you can actually gain information by throwing information away]{.bg-light-red .black} - In taking a simple arithmetic mean, we discard the individuality of the measures, subsuming them to one summary. ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} ![](../../../../materials/images/SevenPillarsStigler.jpeg){width=300} ::: :::: --- ## Brad Pitt: Throwing it All Away ### What was he throwing away? ::::: columns ::: {.column width="45%"} data table here ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} "OBP" as aggregate column explanation here ::: ::::: --- ## Counting Letters with Sherlock Holmes {.center} --- ## Sherlock Holmes: The Adventure of the Dancing Men :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="40%"} In the Sherlock Holmes story, [The Adventure of the Dancing Men](https://www.gutenberg.org/files/108/108-h/108-h.htm#chap03), a criminal known to one of the characters communicates with her using a childish/child-like drawing which looks like this: ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} ![Am Here, Abe Slaney](../../../../materials/images/holmes-message-1.jpg) How would Holmes decipher this message? ::: :::: --- ## Sherlock Holmes: The Adventure of the Dancing Men :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="55%"} - Using Conjectures: Symbols -> Letters - Holmes deduces that the most common letter in the message is "E" - He then deduces that the second most common letter is "T" ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} ![Zipf's Law](../../../../materials/images/zipf.png){height=200} - Based on well-known ***Counts*** of letters (Zipf's Law) ::: :::: --- ## What Charts work for counting? | Variable #1 | Variable #2 | Chart Names | Chart Shape | |:-----------:|:-----------:|:-----------:|:-------------------------------------:| | Qual | None | Bar Chart | {{< iconify ion bar-chart size=4x >}} | ::: {.smaller} Bar are used to show "counts" and "tallies" with respect to Qual variables. For instance, in a survey, how many people vs Gender? In a Target Audience survey on *Weekly Consumption*, how many low, medium, or high expenditure people? ::: --- ## Where's our Data? OK, Let's get some data to count: Penguins Data And let's for now use a pre-set Workflow in Orange Barchart Workflow --- ## Workflow#1: Bar Charts - We will look at the data - Make a Data dictionary - Identify the Qual and Quant variables - Prepare Counts and Bar Charts wrt Qual variables - In Orange! Point, Click, and See! --- ### {{< iconify streamline dictionary-language-book-solid >}} Data Dictionary ::: callout-note ### Qualitative Variables - `species`: Species of the penguin (Qual) - `island`: Island where the penguin was observed (Qual) - `sex`: Male / Female penguin (Qual) ::: ::: callout-note ### Quantitative Variables - `bill_length_mm`: Length of the penguin's bill in millimeters (Quant) - `bill_depth_mm`: Depth of the penguin's bill in millimeters (Quant) - `flipper_length_mm`: Length of the penguin's flipper in millimeters (Quant) - `body_mass_g`: Mass of the penguin in grams (Quant) ::: --- ## {{< iconify material-symbols query-stats >}} Counting our Data :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: callout-note ### Research Question Are there more penguins of some `species` than there are in others? ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: callout-note ### Research Question Are the penguin polulations on different `island` the same? ::: ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-2-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: ::: :::: --- ## {{< iconify mingcute thought-line >}} Wait, But Why? - Counts first give you an absolute sense of how much data you have. - Counts by different Qual variables give you a sense of the **combinations** you have in your data: $(Male/Female) * (Species) * (Island)$ (Say 2 \* 3 \* 3 = 18 combinations in the data) - Counts then give an idea whether your data is lop-sided - Since the X-axis in bar charts is *Qualitative* (the bars don't touch, remember!) it is possible to sort the bars at will. --- ## Nursery Rhymes with Ben Affleck {.center} --- ## Who was Solomon Grundy? {{< downloadthis data/US_births_2000-2014_SSA.csv dname="US_births_2000-2014_SSA" label="Download the US Births data" icon="database-fill-down" type="info" >}} --- ## Who was Solomon Grundy? --- ## Being a Mermaid with Katie Ledecky {.center} --- ## Being a Mermaid with Katie Ledecky --- ## Jack and Rose lived happily ever after {.center} --- ## Jack and Rose lived happily ever after? :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} - What are the chances? - What did the chances depend on? ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![](../../../../materials/images/titanic.webp){height=400} ::: :::: --- ## Jack and Rose lived happily ever after? - Let's get the `titanic` data, using the `Datasets` widget in Orange. - There were 2201 passengers, as per this dataset. - And let's use a pre-set Workflow in Orange Mosaic Chart Workflow --- ### {{< iconify streamline dictionary-language-book-solid >}} Data Dictionary: `titanic`{.smaller} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: callout-note ### Quantitative Data None. ::: ::: callout-note ### Qualitative Data - `survived`: (chr) yes or no - `status`: (chr) Class of Travel, else "crew" - `age`: (chr) Adult, Child - `sex`: (chr) Male / Female. ::: ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ![](../../../../materials/images/Orange/titanic-data-table.png){height=500 width=450} ::: :::: --- ## {{< iconify tabler variable >}} What kind of Data Variables will we choose? | Variable #1 | Variable #2 | Chart Names | Chart Shape | |:---------------:|:---------------:|:-----------------:|:------------------:| | Qual | Qual | ~~Pies~~, Mosaic Charts | {{< iconify carbon chart-marimekko size=4x >}} | Here, $area \sim count$, so the area of the tile is proportional to the count of observations in that tile. --- ### {{< iconify material-symbols query-stats >}} Research Question #1{.smaller} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: callout-note What is the dependence of `survived` upon `sex`? ::: ![](../../../../materials/images/Orange/titanic-sex-survived.png) ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: callout-note - Note the huge imbalance in `survived` with `sex` - Men have clearly perished in larger numbers than women. - Colouring shows large [*positive* residuals]{style="color: blue;"} for men who died, and large [*negative* residuals]{style="color: red;"} for women who died. So sadly Jack is far more likely to have died than Rose. ::: ::: :::: --- ### {{< iconify material-symbols query-stats >}} Research Question #2{.smaller} :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: callout-note ### How does `survived` depend upon `status`? ::: ![](../../../../materials/images/Orange/titanic-mosaic-survived-status.png) ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: callout-note - Crew has seen deaths in large numbers, - as seen by the large [*negative* residual]{style="color: red;"} for crew-survivals. - [First Class passengers have had speedy access to the boats](https://youtu.be/kQ8WsD9AGX4) and have survived in larger proportions than say second or third class. - There is a large [*positive* residual]{style="color: blue;"} for first-class survivals. - Rose travelled `first class` and Jack was `third class`. So again the odds are stacked against him. ::: ::: :::: --- ## What are these Residuals anyhow?{.smaller} When differences between the actual and expected counts are large, we deduce that one Qual variable has an effect on the other Qual variable. (speaking counts-wise or ratio-wise) ::: {.cell layout-ncol="3"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Actual Counts](index_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-3-1.png){width=960} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Expected Counts!!](index_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-3-2.png){width=960} ::: ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Tile-Wise Differences = Residuals](index_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-3-3.png){width=960} ::: ::: --- ## The Art of Surprise with Gabbar Singh {.center} --- ## The Art of Surprise with Gabbar Singh Why is this slide always showing up? --- ---

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
